With regards to Germany, the law  ("Eigenmittelbeschluss-Ratifizierungsgesetz - ERatG") that is obligatory has already been agreed upon in both chambers: by the Bundestag on 25 March 2021, by the Bundesrat (the upper chamber consisting of representatives of the Laender) today 26 March 2021.
https://www.spiegel.de/politik/deutschland/corona-bundesverfassungsgericht-bremst-gesetz-zu-eu-hilfsfonds-vorerst-a-ad0998bb-20d5-4c55-814c-a41f7364e02f
https://www.bundestag.de/ausschuesse/a08/Anhoerungen/827408-827408 For the law to enter into force (and the own resource decision be ratified by Germany, and as a whole) President Steinmeier would have to sign the law. Currently, the German supreme court ("Bundesverfassungsgericht") stopped the signature due to a constitutional complaint appealed by a German party (AfD) and a few thousand signees concerning alleging the funding of the EU via debt being unconstitutional. The supreme court will fast-track an investigation and a decision about the complaint, and probably within a month, it will judge about constitutionality, and whether all additional mandatory obligations of the German government (informing the Bundestag, sufficient majority etc) will have been met. It is, however, highly uncertain, whether the supreme court decision will be published in time for the German president's signature and the formal notification of the Council to happen in time for this question before 01 April 2021.

https://www.consilium.europa.eu/media/48759/16-vtc-ecofin-agenda.pdf
 followed up by this press release:
"Ministers also took stock of the implementation of the Recovery and Resilience Facility and progress in the ratification of the own resources decision. Following the entry into force of the regulation establishing the Recovery and Resilience Facility (RRF) in February, member states can now officially submit their recovery and resilience plans to the Commission. The presidency noted that many member states are already at an advanced stage of preparation of their plans and recalled that European-wide recovery will benefit from the swift implementation of the RRF. The Commission highlighted areas where further progress is needed and underlined the need for full alignment between the draft national plans and the RRF regulation."
https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/meetings/ecofin/2021/03/16/ It proves that the Own Resource Decision is high on the list of priorities, and there's frequent exchange on top government level. However, a more detailed background info states:
"Ministers will take stock of the implementation of the Recovery and Resilience Facilityand progress in the ratification of the own resources decision. The presidency will provide an overview of the state of play. Ministers will also discuss the priorities of the recovery and resilience plans following their exchange of views on the plans in January and February. The regulation establishing the Recovery and Resilience Facility entered into force on 19 February. This means that member states can now officially submit their recovery and resilience plans to the Commission, once they are ready. They have until 30 April, as a rule, to do this. Once a plan has been submitted, the Commission will generally have up to two months to assess it. After that, the Council will have four weeks to adopt its decision on the final approval the plan. After the plans have been approved, the Commission will sign grant and loan agreements with the member states, commit resources and proceed with the payment of the pre-financing (13% of total grants and loans) within two months. However, such resources can be committed only if the own resources decision will have been ratified in the meantime." If plans will have been submitted by 30 April and
the European Commission has two months (until 30 June) for assessment/final approval,
and the Council has four weeks (28 July 2021) for adoption,
it seems a ratification until 30 June will suffice in order to avoid frictions in the European Commission operational procedure "with the payment of the pre-financing (13% of total grants and loans)" by law:
"However, such resources can be committed only if the own resources decision will have been ratified in the meantime."
This takes quite some pressure and urgency from the ratification process, however, parliaments (or whoever is competent by member state constitutions) will target a ratification asap before 30 June 2021, thus apparently there's no official target or hard deadline.
